attributes.alt: Cover for Oscar and the Cricket: A Book About Moving and Rolling by Geoff Waring. Cover shows a cat and a grasshopper in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the letters
engage children with a song about how a bus moves, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What does Oscar make the ball do?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
How can we make things go?
Choose a book. What is it about?
How can you pretend you are Oscar? What can you act out from the story?
How can you move a ping-pong ball across the table without touching it?
Draw or write about one way you can move on the playground.
Make Cricket. How can you make him jump?
How many letters are in your name? Write your name.
Build a rough path and a smoother path.

attributes.alt: Cover for Oscar and the Cricket: A Book About Moving and Rolling by Geoff Waring. Cover shows a cat and a grasshopper in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the  Mind Builder.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Manage transitions and adapt  to change in activities or situations.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Guide children to make connections between force and motion.
How can we make things go?
Choose a book. Why did you choose it?
Can you act out examples of how you push and pull to make things in the kitchen move?
Use more force to push counters across a table and use less force. How are they different?
Make a picture of yourself rolling a ball. What makes the ball stop?
What materials can you use to make a ramp? Can you roll a ball down the ramp?
Can you use the dry erase board to make the letters Qq and Rr?
Build train tracks to pull a train with three cars.

attributes.alt: Cover for Oscar and the Cricket: A Book About Moving and Rolling by Geoff Waring. Cover shows a cat and a grasshopper in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to further practice the concept of push and pull, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
How do you know that Oscar gave the ball a great BIG push the last time?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use information to compare and contrast.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Guide children as they make art using their breath to push paint across paper.
Reinforce understanding of the effects of the push force.
How can we make things go?
What forces do you use when you take a book from the library and then return it to the shelf?
Why is it good to be strong?
Push and pull Connecting Cubes to build a tall tower.
How do you use the push or pull force on the playground? Can you draw and write about it?
Make a painting by only pushing and pulling a paintbrush dipped in paint across a piece of paper.
Arrange the uppercase and lowercase letter tiles in ABC order.
Build a truck that can pull or push small blocks.

attributes.alt: Cover for Oscar and the Cricket: A Book About Moving and Rolling by Geoff Waring. Cover shows a cat and a grasshopper in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about different words for
, engage children with a rhyme about forces, and introduce vocabulary
Read interactively and connect to the Concept Question:
How can we make things go?
Write own name; Use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Manage transitions and adapt  to change in activities or situations.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Help children identify a plant or animal that would be hard to move because of its size.
Invite children to draw a picture of a great big enormous plant or animal.
Have children recognize and practice writing their own names.
How can we make things go?
How is pushing one book across the table different from pushing a pile of four books?
Pretend to fly a kite and pull it along on a windy day.
Can you think of ways to build something by pushing and pulling the Connecting Cubes?
What can you move by pushing with your feet? Draw and write about it!
Can you make three different-sized boxes for Oscar to push and move? Can you put them in order from smallest to largest?
Build three car ramps that are different lengths and put them in order—short, shorter, shortest.

attributes.alt: Cover for Oscar and the Cricket: A Book About Moving and Rolling by Geoff Waring. Cover shows a cat and a grasshopper in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out a scene from the story and to introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What does Oscar learn about moving and rolling?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share and repeat the details in  a text.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How would you use the push and pull forces to move a big object?
How can we make things go?
Can you find a book that shows a truck pulling something? What sound does the truck make?
Can you pretend to be a monkey swinging from the branches of the trees?
Who can move a ping pong ball the farthest without touching it with your hands? How do you know whose ping pong ball went the farthest?
How does it feel to be pushed on a swing? Write about it.
Create a cat that looks like Oscar.
Can you build a straight road? Push a car on it to see how far  it goes.
